action.action-desc: Mr. Taylor (for himself, Mr. Harris of North Carolina, Mr. Rulli, Mr. Stutzman, Mr. Collins, Mr. Hamadeh of Arizona, Mr. Wied, and Mr. Gill of Texas) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and in addition to the Committee on the Judiciary, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To require agencies to repeal ten existing regulations before issuing a new regulation, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Regulation Decimation Act.

section.header: Repeal of regulations required before issuance of a new rule

paragraph.text: An agency may not issue a rule unless such agency has repealed ten or more rules described in paragraph (4) that, to the extent practicable, are related to the rule.

subparagraph.text: An agency may not issue a major rule unless—

clause.text: such agency has repealed ten or more rules described in paragraph (4) that, to the extent practicable, are related to the major rule; and
the cost of the new major rule is less than or equal to the cost of the rules repealed.

subparagraph.text: For any rule issued in accordance with subparagraph (A), the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs of the Office of Management and Budget must have certified that the cost of the new major rule is equal to or less that the cost of the rules repealed.

paragraph.text: Any rule repealed under paragraph (1) or (2) shall be published in the Federal Register.

subparagraph.text: applies to any rule or major rule that imposes a cost or responsibility on a nongovernmental person or a State or local government; and
shall not apply to any rule or major rule—

clause.text: that relates to the internal policy or practice of an agency or procurement by the agency; or
that is being revised to be less burdensome to decrease requirements imposed by the rule or cost of compliance.

paragraph.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the head of each agency shall submit to Congress and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget a report that includes a review of each rule of the agency that identifies whether that rule is costly, ineffective, duplicative, or outdated, including a list of any other unnecessary regulatory restriction of the agency that is costly, ineffective, duplicative, or outdated.

Not later than 5 years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the President shall submit to Congress a report on the number of rules in effect and the status of the reduction of rules over the previous 5 years.

subparagraph.text: The term agency has the meaning given that term in section 551 of title 5, United States Code.
The term major rule has the meaning given that term in section 804 of title 5, United States Code.
The term rule has the meaning given that term in section 551 of title 5, United States Code.
The term State means each of the several States, the District of Columbia, each territory or possession of the United States, and each federally recognized Indian Tribe.
